shortDescription: The Jewish Feast of Weeks (Shavuot), fifty days after Passover, commemorated the giving of the Torah at Sinai. On this day, Peter preached his Pentecost sermon, quoting Joel's prophecy about the Spirit being poured out on all flesh (Acts 2).
fullDescription: Shavuot (Hebrew: 'Weeks'), known in Greek as Pentecost ('Fiftieth'), is one of the three pilgrimage festivals of ancient Israel. Occurring fifty days after Passover, it originally celebrated the wheat harvest but became associated with the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai. In Acts 2, on the day of Pentecost, the Holy Spirit descended on the gathered disciples with tongues of fire, and Peter delivered his powerful sermon quoting Joel's prophecy: 'I will pour out my Spirit upon all flesh.' This moment marks the birth of the Church and demonstrates how God's Spirit now fulfills what the written Torah pointed toward.

petrinePerspective.description: Peter's central role in the Pentecost event and the birth of the Church
petrinePerspective.leadershipRole: Peter stood up with the eleven to address the crowd (Acts 2:14), establishing his role as spokesman for the apostles
petrinePerspective.propheticInterpretation: Peter demonstrated how to interpret Scripture christologically, showing that Joel and David prophesied about Christ and the Spirit
petrinePerspective.call to action: Peter's call to repent and be baptized set the pattern for Christian proclamation and initiation

petrinePerspective.universalScope: Peter's quotation of Joel ('all flesh... sons and daughters... servants and handmaidens') anticipated the later extension of the Gospel to Gentiles (Acts 10)

theologicalThemes.description: Jeremiah prophesied a new covenant with law written on hearts (Jeremiah 31:31-34). Pentecost fulfills this through the Spirit.
The Spirit is poured out on all flesh - not just prophets, priests, and kings, but sons and daughters, servants and handmaidens.
Pentecost marks the birth of the Church as the Spirit-empowered community of believers.
The Spirit's coming fulfilled Jesus's promise: 'You shall receive power when the Holy Spirit has come upon you, and you shall be my witnesses' (Acts 1:8).
Many languages, one message - Pentecost demonstrates unity amid diversity, reversing Babel's confusion.
